titleStmt.title: Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 1 Title: Adaptive social decisions are disrupted in highly antagonistic individuals

affiliation.orgName: The Mortimer B. Zuckerman Mind Brain Behavior Institute
Department of Psychology, University Center for Human Values

analytic.title: Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 1 Title: Adaptive social decisions are disrupted in highly antagonistic individuals

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Background Healthy social functioning relies on an ability to form accurate representations of others' character and to utilize the representations to guide decisions. Here, we take a transdiagnostic longitudinal approach to investigate disrupted social decision-making in psychopathology. Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 2 Methods We obtained transdiagnostic antagonism symptom scores from a battery of standardized questionnaires in an online US sample nationally representative for age, sex, and ethnicity. Participants completed a Moral Inference Task where they made a series of predictions about the moral decisions of both a selfish and a generous agent, and periodically reported their beliefs about the agents' moral character. Participants were incentivized to form accurate representations of the agents' tendencies as they later played an economic game where they could entrust money to the agents. We characterized the behavioral phenotypes of antagonism in forming social representations and using the representations to make adaptive social decisions. Results Participants with high antagonism (1) held strong, pessimistic prior expectations, (2) were less accurate in predicting others' moral decisions, (3) were more confident about their subjective impressions, and (4) made maladaptive trust decisions. Conclusions We found that disrupted social representations are specific to the latent dimension of antagonism and stable over time. The findings emphasize the role of social representations in adaptive social decisions in antagonism, providing a potential target for interventions.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Healthy social functioning relies on an ability to form accurate representations of others' character 1 . Learning whether other people are likely to be generous and helpful, or selfish and harmful can guide adaptive social decisions such as deciding whom to trust. The ability to form accurate social representations, however, varies across individuals 2,3 and is impaired in some psychopathology 4 . Impairment in this ability can result in social dysfunctions. For example, overly pessimistic representations of others can lead to social withdrawal, while overly optimistic representations can lead to placing trust in the wrong people. To understand altered social functioning in psychopathology, it is crucial to identify how psychopathology disrupts the formation of representations of others and how those representations relate to social decisions.

Antagonism is defined in the DSM-5 Alternative Model of Personality Disorders as a collection of traits and behaviors that "put the individual at odds with other people," including an inflated sense of self-importance, an expectation of special treatment, and a callous disregard for the needs and feelings of others, often leading to manipulative or exploitative behaviors 5 . This trait is present across the DSM-5 6 , Hierarchical Taxonomy of Psychopathology (HiTOP) 7 , the Comprehensive Assessment of Traits Relevant to Personality Disorder 8 , and the Five Factor Model (FFM) 9 . It is often discussed in relation to its impact on social functioning 10,11 However, this literature paints an inconclusive picture of how antagonism relates to the ability to form social representations 12,13 . In particular, it remains elusive as to how highly antagonistic individuals learn about other people and incorporate learned information in their social decisions. Often there is no established "ground truth" to evaluate individuals' social representations of the targets, and past literature has instead leaned on consensus among raters or on self-ratings 11,12,14,15 . Thus, understanding the impacts of antagonism would benefit from an objective measure of accurate representation, such as predictions about target behavior, in addition to subjective ratings.

div.head: Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 4
div.p: An additional factor that perturbs understanding the impact of antagonism is that many findings concern specific disorders for which antagonism is one of multiple symptoms (e.g., antisocial personality disorder, borderline personality disorder) 16,17 , rather than the transdiagnostic trait of antagonism. In doing so, research shows idiosyncratic phenotypes across disorders. For instance, antisocial personality disorder and psychopathy are characterized by reduced emotional recognition and less empathic understanding [18][19][20][21] . Studies on borderline personality disorder (BPD) show related but distinct phenotypes, such as higher confidence about the ability to identify other people's affective states, albeit average ability to recognize them 22 , and heightened certainty in beliefs about selfish moral character 23 . Patients with BPD also show hypersensitivity to social threats 24 and low cooperation 25 . A transdiagnostic approach to studying the impact of antagonism on social interactions is needed to identify shared underlying mechanisms that connect the idiosyncratic phenotypes across disorders and reveal how antagonism affects the ability to form accurate representations of others.

To summarize, past literature investigating the relationship between antagonism and the ability to form social representations has several limitations. First, clinical work has focused on single disorders, potentially missing insights that would arise from considering antagonism as a transdiagnostic trait. Second, past research is often challenging to interpret because they rely on subjective ratings of personality traits which are difficult to connect to "ground truth" signals.

To address these limitations, here we take a transdiagnostic approach and use more objective measures of social representation accuracy. We use a Moral Inference Task 23,26,27 to precisely measure several related facets of social cognition, from prior beliefs to the formation of representations, and the behavioral consequences of these representations on social decisions. Past research using this task has characterized a cluster of deficits in social representations that Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 5 may be related to antagonism. Siegel and colleagues 27 discovered that exposure to violence -a set of life experiences predictive of antagonism 28 -impaired the ability to appropriately discern others with distinct moral character, impacting both the formation of impressions and trust behaviors. Similarly, people diagnosed with BPD formed more rigid negative beliefs about others' moral character 23 . These results suggest that antagonism may lead to impairments in various aspects of social representations. However, it remains elusive as to how antagonism, as a latent dimension that manifests in different disorders and behaviors, is connected to the accurate representation of others in a manner that can support healthy social relationships.

Moreover, the stability of the relationship between antagonism and diminished social functioning remains uncertain. Given that much of the previous research has captured only a single snapshot in time [10][11][12][13]15 , drawing definitive conclusions about the potential utility of a transdiagnostic phenotype as a biomarker for targeted interventions becomes challenging.

Here, we take a longitudinal approach to investigate the stability of the relationship between antagonism and social representation accuracy over a period of 6 months. We predicted that antagonism would be associated with (1) reduced accuracy in representing others' character and (2) impaired social decisions that misplace trust in selfish individuals, and (3) that these relationships would be stable across time.

div.head: Participants
div.p: We recruited participants from online crowdsourcing platform Prolific (www.prolific.com). The participants were a US adult sample, nationally representative for age, sex, and race (N=2761, mean age=39.9 years; Supplementary Figure 1 for age, sex, and race distributions). A subset of participants completed the Moral Inference Task described below (N=1196; nationally representative of age, sex, and race). All participants provided informed consent and were Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 6 compensated for their participation, according to the protocols approved by Yale University Institutional Review Board (IRB #2000022385).

div.head: Study Overview
div.p: In this study, we investigated transdiagnostic symptoms and social representations across time (see Figure 1A). Participants (N=1196) first performed the Moral Inference Task with a neutral agent and completed a questionnaire battery described below at the initial time point (T0).

Those who successfully completed the Moral Inference Task with a neutral agent and passed attention checks embedded in the questionnaire battery were invited back to complete the Moral Inference Task again the same day (T1). The Moral Inference Task at T1 involved two agents with varying degrees of harm preferences (generous and selfish agents). Approximately one

week following the initial assessment at T0, we invited participants to complete the Moral Inference Task once again (N=1007), with generous and selfish agents (T2). To examine the long-term reliability of effects observed at T1 and T2, we re-invited participants approximately 6 months after the initial assessment (T3). At T3, participants (N=594) were asked to complete both the Moral Inference Task and the questionnaire battery. An additional sample (N=1565) was recruited to complete the questionnaire battery to ensure enough power for Factor Analysis. All participants' questionnaire battery data (N=2761) were used to identify transdiagnostic latent symptom dimensions.
Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 7

div.head: Moral Inference Task
div.p: A sample of 1196 participants performed a Moral Inference Task 23,26,27 , where they made inferences about agents making moral decisions (see Figure 2A). Participants were tasked with predicting the choices made by these agents in the following scenario. The cover story was that the agents played a game as a Decider with their partner, the Receiver. Agents had to choose between two options involving monetary reward for the Decider and electrical shocks for the Receiver: one option had a greater monetary reward for the Decider but inflicted more pain on the Receiver ("harm" option), while the other option yielded a smaller profit for the Decider but spared the Receiver from some pain ("help" option). These agents had varying degrees of harm preferences: a "generous" agent required more monetary reward to harm others, making fewer "harm" choices, while a "selfish" agent made more "harm" choices even for smaller profit. A "neutral" agent displayed no bias towards either "harm" or "help" choices. Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 10 Before observing the gameplay and making predictions, participants were first prompted to report their prior beliefs about the moral character of the upcoming agent (on a scale ranging from "nice" to "nasty") as well as their level of certainty about these character impressions (Figure 2A, Left panel). Then, participants started a prediction phase in which they learned about different agents' harm preferences (Figure 2A prediction trials for each of the generous and selfish agents. The neutral agent was presented in the sessions at the initial (T0) and the final (T3) time points, and the selfish and generous agents were presented at the T1, T2, and T3 time points. While making predictions, approximately every 3 trials, participants were asked to report their current beliefs about the agent's moral character and the certainty of their beliefs. Importantly, participants were incentivized to learn the agent's tendencies as they played an economic game with the agent after the prediction phase for each agent (Figure 2A Right panel). In a trust game, participants were endowed with money (10 cents), and they could entrust some of the money to the agent, which would then be tripled and sent to the agent, who would subsequently return a portion of it to the participant. Participants repeated these phases (i.e., prior belief report, prediction phase, and trust game) for each agent.

div.head: Self-Report Clinical and Transdiagnostic Symptom Questionnaire Battery
div.p: Participants completed a battery of transdiagnostic symptom questionnaires. Clinical 34 ; for a full list of questionnaires, see Supplementary Table 1). We did not collect data on psychiatric diagnoses by a medical doctor or medication histories.

div.head: Factor Analysis
div.p: We performed a factor analysis to reduce the latent symptom dimensions (factors) from the questionnaire battery (281 items from 16 questionnaires, N=2761; Figure 1B). Factor analysis was performed using the 'factanal' function in R package 'Psych'. We determined the number of factors based on the Cattell-Nelson-Gorsuch (CNG) test that compares the slope of all possible sets of three adjacent eigenvalues and identifies the number of factors where the difference between two successive slopes is the greatest, using R package 'nFactors' 35,36 . The CNG test indicated that our data were best accounted for with a 3-factor latent structure ( Figure 1B).

Based on the questionnaire items' loadings on each factor, we labeled the three factors (see Supplementary Table 2 for factor loadings). "Antagonism" emerged as one of the factors. In addition, there were two additional factors, "internalizing symptoms", and "detachment." "Internalizing symptoms" mainly captured anxiety and depression, and affective lability, and "detachment" encompassed items measuring a lack of perceived social support and attachment.

div.head: Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 12
Antagonism predicts strong pessimistic prior beliefs about moral character
div.p: We first assessed participants' expectations about the agents before any gameplay. On a nice Figure 3). This interaction showed that pessimistic expectations were held with more certainty in high antagonism. This suggests the specificity of pessimistic prior beliefs for antagonism.

div.head: Antagonism predicts lower accuracy in predicting agents' harm preferences
div.p: We next examined participants' ability to learn the agents' harm preferences as they observed agents' choices and predicted agents' decisions accordingly. Overall, prediction accuracy was Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 16 We then examined the long-term reliability of the relationships, by investigating the relationship between antagonism and prediction accuracy measured approximately six months after the initial measure (T3). Replicating results at T1 and T2, antagonism at T3 was associated with reduced prediction accuracy at T3 (β = -0.123 ± 0.026, t = -4.662, p < 0.001; Figure 4A Reduced prediction accuracy was a phenotype unique to antagonism. Internalizing symptoms predicted higher, not lower, accuracy (β = 0.086 ± 0.024, t = 3.520, p < 0.001). These results were reliable at T2 (β = 0.085 ± 0.026, t = 3.255, p < 0.01), and internalizing symptoms at T3 predicted higher accuracy at T3 (β = 0.100 ± 0.036, t = 2.760, p < 0.01). Detachment was also associated with increased accuracy at T2 (β = 0.052 ± 0.023, t = 2.251, p < 0.05), but not at T1 (β = 0.042 ± 0.022, t = 1.935, p = 0.053) and T3 (β = 0.046 ± 0.031, t = 1.492, p = 0.136). To investigate whether antagonism is associated with the valence and certainty of participants' subjective impressions of the agents' moral character, we ran a mixed-effect linear regression.

div.head: Antagonism predicts reduced subjective differentiation between selfish and generous agents
div.p: While antagonism did not predict the overall valence of impressions about the agents (β = 0.008 ± 0.005, t = 1.395, p = 0.163), it moderated the difference in impressions between agents, such that higher antagonism predicted a smaller difference in impressions between the generous and selfish agents (β = -0.013 ± 0.002, t = -6.712, p < 0.001; Figure 4B left panel), driven by more positive impressions of selfish agents (selfish β = 0.014 ± 0.006, t = 2.227, p < 0.05; generous β = 0.001 ± 0.006, t = 0.174, p = 0.862). Notably, despite impaired differentiation between agents, individuals with high antagonism reported higher certainty of their impressions (β = 0.027 ± 0.006, t = 4.811, p < 0.001; Figure 4B left panel). Antagonism did not moderate the effect of agents on certainty ratings (β = -0.003 ± 0.002, t = -1.480, p = 0.139), with antagonism predicting more certain impressions for both the generous agent (β = 0.026 ± 0.006, t = 4.039, p < 0.001) and the selfish agent (β = 0.029 ± 0.006, t = 4.789, p < 0.001).

We tested the reliability of the relationship between antagonism and reduced differentiation in forming impressions. While antagonism at T0 did not predict reduced differentiation in impression ratings at T2 (β = -0.002 ± 0.002, t = -0.877, p = 0.380; Figure 4B middle panel), a long-term replication at T3 revealed that antagonism did moderate the relationship between agents' harm preferences and participants' impressions, showing reduced differentiation between agents with distinctive harm preferences (β = -0.023 ± 0.002, t = -9.018, p < 0.001; Figure 4B right panel). We then tested whether antagonism is reliably associated with increased certainty about impressions. Individuals with high antagonism continued to report higher certainty about their impressions at T2 (β = 0.029 ± 0.006, t = 4.491, p < 0.001; Figure 4B Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 18 middle panel), for both generous agent (β = 0.024 ± 0.007, t = 3.327, p < 0.001) and selfish agent (β = 0.033 ± 0.007, t = 4.929, p < 0.001). Antagonism's association with high certainty in impression was replicated in T3 (β = 0.018 ± 0.008, t = 2.362, p < 0.05; Figure 4B right panel), driven by certain impressions about the selfish agent (β = 0.028 ± 0.008, t = 3.286, p < 0.01) while certainty was not higher for the generous agent (β = 0.009 ± 0.009, t = 1.026, p = 0.305).

To test whether higher certainty despite reduced subjective differentiation is a unique phenotype of antagonism, we examined internalizing symptoms and detachment across time. In contrast to antagonism, internalizing symptoms predicted increased subjective differentiation between agents across time (T1 β = 0.021 ± 0.002, t = 8.562, p < 0.001; T2 β = 0.015 ± 0.002, t = 6.071, p < 0.001; T3 β = 0.025 ± 0.003, t = 7.213, p < 0.001), while it did not show significant association with reported certainty (T1 β = 0.004 ± 0.007, t = 0.524, p = 0.600; T2 β = 0.002 ± 0.008, t = 0.245, p = 0.806; T3 β = 0.003 ± 0.011, t = 0.323, p = 0.747).

While individuals with high detachment had an overall negative impression (T1 β = -0.019 ± 0.006, t = -3.131, p < 0.01; T2 β = -0.017 ± 0.007, t = -2.566, p < 0.05; T3 β = -0.024 ± 0.009, t = -2.659, p < 0.01), the relationship between detachment and subjective impressions was less consistent. They showed reduced subjective differentiation at T3 (β = -0.008 ± 0.003, t = -2.722, p < 0.01), but this effect was not observed at T1 (β = 0.000 ± 0.002, t = 0.152, p = 0.879) or T2 (β = -0.000 ± 0.002, t = -0.008, p = 0.993). Regarding the certainty of impressions, detachment predicted low, not high, certainty in impressions at both T1 (β = -0.038 ± 0.006, t = -5.886, p < 0.001) and T2 (β = -0.030 ± 0.007, t = -4.403, p < 0.001), but this effect was not observed in T3

(β = -0.017 ± 0.009, t = -1.906, p = 0.057). Collectively, these findings show that the phenotype characterized by impaired subjective differentiation between generous and selfish agents while maintaining high certainty is specific to antagonism.

div.head: Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 19
Antagonism predicts reduced behavioral differentiation between selfish and generous agents
div.p: Healthy social functioning requires us to adapt our decisions to trust others according to how likely they are to benefit or betray us. To this end, we next investigated how people show To test whether antagonism is associated with suboptimal trust decisions, we performed a mixed-effect linear regression predicting the entrust amount with agent and their interaction with antagonism. While antagonism did not predict an overall significant decrease in entrust amount (β = 0.008 ± 0.009, t = 0.848, p = 0.397), antagonism predicted a significantly smaller difference between the amount entrusted to the generous and the selfish agents (β = -0.031 ± 0.011, t = -2.782, p < 0.01; Figure 4C left panel). Further analysis through planned contrasts did not reveal any significant effects for individual agents (generous β = -0.008 ± 0.010, t = -0.795, p = 0.427; selfish β = 0.023 ± 0.012, t = 1.929, p = 0.054).

We then tested the reliability of reduced behavioral differentiation between generous and selfish agents in antagonism. Antagonism at T0 continued to predict impaired differentiation in entrust decisions at T2 (β = -0.040 ± 0.013, t = -3.060, p < 0.01; Figure 4C middle panel). In a long-term replication at T3, antagonism again predicted entrusting more similar amounts to the two agents (β = -0.050 ± 0.017, t = -3.041, p < 0.01; Figure 4C right panel).

div.head: Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 20
div.p: This phenotype of impaired behavioral differentiation was specific to antagonism, and internalizing symptoms and detachment did not predict significant differences between agents across time (internalizing symptoms T1 β = 0.024 ± 0.014, t = 1.693, p = 0.091; T2 β = 0.020 ± 0.016, t = 1.236, p = 0.217; T3 β = 0.036 ± 0.023, t = 1.586, p = 0.113; detachment T1 β = 0.023 ± 0.013, t = 1.791, p = 0.074; T2 β = 0.024 ± 0.014, t = 1.677, p = 0.094; T3 β = 0.016 ± 0.019, t = 0.846, p = 0.398). Moreover, neither factor showed a consistent association with overall entrust amount (internalizing symptoms T1 β = 0.016 ± 0.012, t = 1.352, p = 0.177; T2 β = 0.003 ± 0.013, t = 0.213, p = 0.831; T3 β = -0.010 ± 0.018, t = -0.539, p = 0.590; detachment T1 β = -0.026 ± 0.011, t = -2.430, p < 0.05; T2 β = -0.014 ± 0.011, t = -1.203, p = 0.229; T3 β = -0.009 ± 0.016, t = -0.570, p = 0.569). Taken together, these results suggest that antagonism is distinctly associated with impaired social behaviors, showing limited ability to adaptively adjust their trust in agents based on the agents' harm preferences.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Forming accurate representations of others' character is key to successful social interactions. These relationships held across a period of six months.

Our findings of disrupted social representations and decisions specifically in antagonism reinforce the dimensional nature of psychopathology and extend work in clinical samples, which yielded inconsistent results across disorders. In particular, psychopathic individuals 19 and those with antisocial personality disorder 18,20,21 were found to be less accurate at representing others while individuals with borderline personality disorder performed similarly to healthy controls 22 .

One potential explanation for this split in past findings is the lack of objectivity in measuring social representation accuracy. Our task provides an objective measure of accuracy by manipulating agents' harm preferences, enabling a comparison of prediction performance against a known ground truth.

Incorporating these objective measures of accuracy allowed us to compare phenotypes across studies utilizing the Moral Inference Task. While prior studies employing the same task failed to detect relationship between prediction accuracy and exposure to violence or BPD diagnosis 23,27 Research on SST has also suggested the use of virtual agents in effectively teaching skills 46 , suggesting potential uses for adaptations of our task. The integration of CBT and SST allows for 16 ; ALS (Affect Lability Scales Short Form) 14 ; GAD (General Anxiety Disorder) 3 ; SAPAS (Standardized Assessment of Personality -Abbreviated Scale) 12 ; MSPSS (Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support) 6 ; AAS-R (Revised Adult Attachment Scale) 8 ; LSRP (Levenson Self-Report Psychopathy Scale) 11

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Moral Inference Task design and performance. (A) Task Design. Participants began by reporting their prior expectations about the moral character of the upcoming agent, on a scale from "nasty" to "nice," along with the certainty of their beliefs (Left panel). They then proceeded to the prediction phase where they learned the agents' harm preferences (Middle panel). During this phase, they performed a prediction task where they made a series of predictions about the agent's choices and received trial-by-trial feedback. They occasionally reported their subjective impressions about the agent (Middle panel). After completing the prediction phase, participants played an economic game with the recently learned agent, where they made a decision regarding how much money to entrust to the agent (Right panel). They repeated these three phases for each agent. (B) Task Performance. Behavioral data showed that prior certainty was positively correlated with the valence of prior beliefs about moral character (nasty to nice, Left panel). Social prediction accuracy was higher for the selfish (red) than the generous (teal) agent, while subjective impressions were more positive and more certain for the generous agent compared to the selfish agent (Middle panel). Participants entrusted a greater amount of money to the generous agent (Right panel). Error bars represent 95% bootstrap confidence intervals. Shaded area denotes 95% confidence intervals.

, Middle panel). During this phase, participants made a series of predictions about the agent's decisions under different pairs of options with profit for the Decider and the number of shocks for the Receivers. After making each prediction, participants received feedback regarding the agent's actual choice and the accuracy of their prediction. There were 30 prediction trials with the neutral agent, and 50

questionnaires assessed a variety of psychiatric illnesses, including general personality disorders (Standardized Assessment of Personality -Abbreviated Scale 29 ), borderline personality disorder (Personality Assessment Inventory -Borderline Features 30 ), and Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 11 generalized anxiety (Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-item scale 31 ). Transdiagnostic questionnaires measured a range of social, affective, and cognitive dysregulations, including attachment (Revised Adult Attachment Scale 32 ), social support (Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support 33 ), and psychopathic traits (Levenson Self-Report Psychopathy Scale

to nasty (0) scale, participants indicated impressions closer to nice than nasty (M = 0.602, SD = 0.224, 95% CI [0.589, 0.614], t(1190) = 15.622, p < 0.001). The certainty of their prior impressions was low (M = 0.391, SD = 0.265, 95% CI [0.376, 0.406], t(1190) = -14.216, p < 0.001), and certainty ratings were lower for more pessimistic expectations (β = 0.019 ± 0.008, t = 2.431, p < 0.05; Figure 2B Left panel). To investigate the prior expectations held by highly antagonistic individuals, we ran linear regression analyses predicting participants' prior impression ratings and certainty ratings. A higher antagonism score was associated with more pessimistic (β = -0.023 ± 0.008, t = -2.822, p < 0.01) and certain (β = 0.076 ± 0.009, t = 8.126, p < 0.001) expectations before observing any of the agent choices. The effect of antagonism on the certainty of prior expectation was significantly moderated by the valence of the expectation (β = -0.028 ± 0.009, t = -3.138, p < 0.01;

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Prior expectation by antagonism. Antagonism predicted higher certainty of prior beliefs, and the prior beliefs' valence moderated the effect such that pessimistic beliefs were held more strongly. For visualization, prior ratings were split into pessimistic (dark red) and optimistic (blue) by median (0.64) on a scale from 0 (nasty) to 1 (nice). Shaded area denotes 95% confidence intervals.The strong, pessimistic prior expectations were unique to antagonism. While higher detachment score also predicted pessimistic expectations (β = -0.029 ± 0.009, t = -3.134, p < 0.01), prior expectations were less certain in higher detachment (β = -0.041 ± 0.011, t = -3.876, p < 0.001), and the certainty of expectation was not significantly moderated by valence (β = -0.003 ± 0.011, t = -0.241, p = 0.809). On the other hand, internalizing symptoms were associated with optimistic expectations (β = 0.031 ± 0.010, t = 3.102, p < 0.01) and low certainty in their expectations (β = -0.025 ± 0.012, t = -2.180, p < 0.05). Internalizing symptoms did not significantly interact with valence in predicting certainty (β = 0.011 ± 0.012, t = 0.919, p = 0.358).

above chance (M = 0.737, SD = 0.098, 95% CI [0.731, 0.743], t(1190) = 83.890, p < 0.001), Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 14 suggesting that participants could learn agents' actual harm preferences. On average, accuracy was higher for selfish agents (M = 0.758, SD = 0.101, 95% CI [0.752, 0.764]) than generous agents (M = 0.716, SD = 0.120, 95% CI [0.710, 0.723], t(1190) = -13.503, p < 0.001; Figure 2B Middle panel). To investigate the relationship between predictions and antagonism, we ran a mixed-effects logistic regression predicting accuracy as a function of antagonism. Higher antagonism predicted lower accuracy (β = -0.149 ± 0.019, t = -7.691, p < 0.001; Figure 4A left panel), controlling for both internalizing symptoms and detachment. This effect was observed for both the generous agent (β = -0.191 ± 0.026, t = -7.203, p < 0.001) and selfish agent (β = -0.159 ± 0.024, t = -6.513, p < 0.001). These results indicate that the ability to form accurate social representations is disrupted in individuals with higher antagonism.We next sought to test the reliability of antagonism's relationship with accuracy. We first tested whether antagonism in the initial measure (T0) continued to predict the accuracy of predictions about agents' harm preferences (T2; approximately a week after T0). Antagonism score at T0 continued to predict reduced prediction accuracy at T2 (β = -0.138 ± 0.022, t = -6.437, p < 0.001;Figure 4Amiddle panel), driven by both generous agent (β = -0.201 ± 0.031, t = -6.588, p < 0.001) and selfish agent (β = -0.124 ± 0.028, t = -4.498, p < 0.001).Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 15

figure.head: Figure 4 .
figure.figDesc: Task performance by antagonism. Antagonism predicted higher certainty of prior beliefs, and the prior beliefs' valence moderated the effect such that pessimistic beliefs were held more strongly (Left panel). (A) Social prediction accuracy was lower for both generous and selfish agents in individuals with higher antagonism. (B) Subjective impressions in individuals with higher antagonism exhibited reduced differentiation between agents, yet they reported higher certainty. (C) Antagonism also predicted reduced behavioral differentiation between agents in terms of amount entrust to each agent. Shaded area denotes 95% confidence intervals.
right panel), for both generous agent (β = -0.187 ± 0.036, t = -5.227, p < 0.001) and selfish agent (β = -0.104 ± 0.034, t = -3.024, p < 0.01).

Throughout the task, participants occasionally reported their overall subjective impressions of the agents. Participants in general held favorable impressions of agents (M = 0.637, SD = 0.148, 95% CI [0.628, 0.645], t(1190) = 31.792, p < 0.001) and reported high certainty about their impression ratings (M = 0.673, SD = 0.160, 95% CI [0.664, 0.682], t(1190) = 37.328, p < 0.001). Suggesting that participants formed impressions according to the agent's harm preferences, impressions of the generous agent were more positive than the impressions of the selfish agent (generous M = 0.732, SD = 0.166, 95% CI [0.723, 0.742] selfish M = 0.541, SD = 0.172, 95% CI [0.531, 0.551], t(1190) = 40.688, p < 0.001; Figure 2B Middle panel). Replicating previous work 26 , the certainty of these impressions was higher for the generous agent than the Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 17 selfish agent (generous M = 0.705, SD = 0.180, 95% CI [0.695, 0.716] selfish M = 0.640, SD = 0.169, 95% CI [0.631, 0.650], t(1190) = 16.178, p < 0.001; Figure 2B Middle panel).

adaptive social behaviors after forming representations about other agents. Participants played a one-shot trust game with each of the agents, after learning about the agents' harm preferences through repeated predictions and observation. Suggesting that participants make adaptive social decisions based on learned information about agents, participants overall entrusted more money to the generous agent than the selfish agent (generous M = 0.814, SD = 0.262, 95% CI [0.799, 0.828] selfish M = 0.638, SD = 0.340, 95% CI [0.618, 0.657], t(1190) = 19.361, p < 0.001; Figure 2B right panel).

For instance, accurate representation guides us to make adaptive decisions about whom to trust. However, social representations are often impaired with psychopathology. Our findings demonstrate that this disrupted social representation and decision-making is specific to the latent dimension of antagonism and stable over time. We show that antagonism is associated with disruptions in all phases of representing others: from prior expectations to decisions based on learned information about others' moral character. Specifically, individuals with high antagonism (1) hold strong, pessimistic prior expectations even before encountering any behavioral evidence supporting such views, (2) are less accurate in predicting others' moral decisions, (3) are more confident about their subjective impressions albeit less accurate, and (4) Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 21 make trust decisions that do not appropriately discern agents with different moral characters.

, our comprehensive analysis, conducted on a large, nationally representative longitudinal sample, reveals impaired social prediction accuracy specifically in the dimension of antagonism. This phenotype of reduced accuracy in prediction may stem from another key feature of antagonism: heightened certainty in their beliefs about others' character. Individuals with high antagonism are highly confident about their impressions, regardless of the valence of the impressions. This overall heightened certainty differs from the selectively increased certainty for selfish character observed in those diagnosed with BPD 23 and in incarcerated individuals 27 . In addition, their indiscriminate high certainty about others' moral character is present even in prior expectations, before any encounter, where they have not yet observed any supporting evidence Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 22 for their impressions. One possible explanation for reduced accuracy is that such strong prior expectations impair subsequent integration 37 of information on the true moral character of others. Strong, negative expectations can impede our ability to form healthy social relationships in several ways. When prior expectations are pessimistic, individuals may not engage in social interactions, which strips the opportunity to update their beliefs 38 . However, our study suggests a more impactful change in the formation of social representation, in that, even when provided with evidence, beliefs do not appropriately incorporate the new information about others' true character. The computational psychiatry literature shows an increased reliance on rigid prior beliefs which impedes social learning in psychosis 39,40 . Given this, it could be the case that, with strong prior expectations, people may require extended experiences to update their beliefs, as a few observations are not enough to sway their rigid beliefs. Thus, both the strong prior expectations and the formation of representation thereafter should be addressed when developing interventions for individuals with antagonism. Our pattern of results in antagonistic individuals suggests that Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) 41 and Social Skills Training (SST) 42 may be useful in addressing social disruptions in individuals high in antagonism. CBT has been shown to be useful in targeting distorted thought patterns and negative beliefs that contribute to antagonistic behavior 43 . Through cognitive restructuring and behavioral experiments, individuals learn to reinterpret social cues, fostering more accurate perceptions and reducing hostile responses 44 . In combination with CBT, SST would provide practical tools for improving interpersonal interactions, such as effective communication and conflict resolution through role-playing scenarios and real life situations 45 .

figure.head: Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 23 a
figure.figDesc: synergistic approach, addressing both the underlying cognitive distortions and the practical aspects of social interaction, promoting positive behavioral change and enhancing overall social functioning.While there are differences in the social impairments with regard to accuracy and confidence in antagonistic individuals, we replicate the results of past work with regard to impaired trust behaviors. Specifically, across studies of people diagnosed with BPD23 , incarcerated individuals with high exposure to violence27 , and antagonism in the general population, participants failed to make adaptive trust decisions that would maximize their financial gain, such as placing more trust in generous others and less trust in selfish others.The discrepancy between the phenotypes of antagonism and those of specific disorders may arise from the fact that specific disorders are a mixture of multiple underlying dimensions. For instance, patients with BPD show both internalizing symptoms and antagonistic externalizing traits46 . Our factor analysis also indicates that tools that assess BPD capture all three latent symptom dimensions. This hints at the possibility that, even though the overall prediction performance appears normal in those who report BPD symptoms, other dimensions, such asinternalizing symptoms that show higher accuracy, may compensate for diminished learning in antagonism. However, this anomaly becomes clear when making trust decisions, as individuals who are diagnosed with BPD have difficulties in differentially placing trust in generous and selfish counterparts 23 . Another possibility is there are subtypes of disorders that have a stronger association with each of the latent symptom dimensions 47 . For example, in BPD there are three distinct subtypes with nuanced differences in symptom presentations 48 . Given the heterogeneity captured within a single disorder, there may also be differences in social representations associated with latent Disrupted social decisions in antagonistic individuals 24 dimensions that would be lost in aggregate analysis. If this is the case, this dimensional approach can provide a way to identify subtypes that exhibit distinct phenotypes. Future research on individuals with a psychiatric diagnosis should explore these possibilities, by measuring the dimensions of symptoms. The dimensional approach to measuring disruptions in social cognition provides a comprehensive understanding of the functional phenotypes of antagonism that subserve such disruptions. We show that antagonism is associated with strong negative prior expectations and their downstream impairments in social representations and decisions. The functional phenotypes of antagonism identified in our study open avenues for future research and provide an opportunity for more targeted interventions. Moving forward, investigating the dynamic interplay between latent dimensions would further advance our understanding of reduced social functions in psychopathology.

Assessment Inventory -Borderline Features), AAS (Revised Adult Attachment Scale), IIP (Inventory of

Violence), CTQ (Childhood Trauma Questionnaire).
All subjects completed the transdiagnostic
questionnaire battery. A subset first performed the Moral Inference Task on a neutral agent (T0) and then
on generous (teal) and selfish (red) agents later the same day (T1; agents presented in a
counterbalanced order). After approximately one week (T2), participants returned to perform the Moral
inference Task again. Participants were re-evaluated approximately six months after the initial
assessment (T3), during which they completed both the Moral Inference Task and the questionnaire
battery. (correlation matrix
illustrates significant correlations across subjects between responses to questionnaire items from 16
questionnaires at T0 (Top panel). The color scales indicate positive (blue) to negative (red) correlation
coefficients. Exploratory Factor Analysis revealed that our data were best accounted for by three latent
factors. Based on the item loadings onto each factor, we labeled these factors as internalizing symptoms,
detachment, and antagonism (Bottom panel). Colors indicate the items in each questionnaire: SPIN
(Social Phobia Inventory), AMI (Apathy Motivation Index), GAD (General Anxiety Disorder), PHQ (Patient

div.head: Supplementary Materials
div.p: . Demographics. US Participants nationally representative of age, sex, and race were recruited from Prolific (prolific.com) using the platform's criteria to match US census data from 2015 at T0. The longitudinal samples (T1 to T3) across time largely retained the initial proportions at T0 for age (A), sex (B), and race (C).
